Article.ArticleTitle: A Novel UVA/ClO<sub>2</sub> Advanced Oxidation Process for the Degradation of Micropollutants in Water.

AbstractText: Ultraviolet (UV)-based advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are increasingly used for the degradation of micropollutants in water and wastewater. This study reports a novel UVA/chlorine dioxide (ClO<sub>2</sub>) AOP based on the photolysis of ClO<sub>2</sub> using energy-efficient UV radiation sources in the UVA range (e.g., UVA-LEDs). At a ClO<sub>2</sub> dosage of 74 μM (5.0 mg L<sup>-1</sup> as ClO<sub>2</sub>) and a UV fluence at 47.5 mJ cm<sup>-2</sup>, the UVA<sub>365</sub>/ClO<sub>2</sub> AOP generated a spectrum of reactive species, including chlorine oxide radicals (ClO<sup>•</sup>), chlorine atoms (Cl<sup>•</sup>), hydroxyl radicals (HO<sup>•</sup>), and ozone at a concentration of ∼10<sup>-13</sup>, ∼10<sup>-15</sup>, ∼10<sup>-14</sup>, and ∼10<sup>-7</sup> M, respectively. A kinetic model to simulate the reactive species generation in the UVA<sub>365</sub>/ClO<sub>2</sub> AOP was established, validated against the experimental results, and used to predict the pseudo-first-order rate constants and relative contributions of different reactive species to the degradation of 19 micropollutants in the UVA<sub>365</sub>/ClO<sub>2</sub> AOP. Compared to the well-documented UVC<sub>254</sub>/chlorine AOP, the UVA<sub>365</sub>/ClO<sub>2</sub> AOP produced similar levels of reactive species at similar oxidant dosages but was much less pH-dependent and required much lower energy input, with much lower formation of chloro-organic byproducts and marginal formation of chlorite and chlorate.
